name: Multiple Binds to the Same Port
description: When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port, other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed.
extended_description: On most systems, a combination of setting the SO_REUSEADDR socket option, and a call to bind() allows any process to bind to a port to which a previous process has bound with INADDR_ANY. This allows a user to bind to the specific address of a server bound to INADDR_ANY on an unprivileged port, and steal its UDP packets/TCP connection.

common_consequences.note: Packets from a variety of network services may be stolen or the services spoofed.

description: Restrict server socket address to known local addresses.

demonstrative_examples.text:
<Intro_Text>This code binds a server socket to port 21, allowing the server to listen for traffic on that port.</Intro_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="bad" Language="C">
                  <xhtml:div>void bind_socket(void) {<xhtml:div style="margin-left:10px;">
                        <xhtml:div>
                           <xhtml:br/>int server_sockfd;<xhtml:br/>int server_len;<xhtml:br/>struct sockaddr_in server_address;<xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:i>/*unlink the socket if already bound to avoid an error when bind() is called*/</xhtml:i>
                           <xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:br/>unlink("server_socket");<xhtml:br/>server_sockfd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);<xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:br/>server_address.sin_family = AF_INET;<xhtml:br/>server_address.sin_port = 21;<xhtml:br/>server_address.sin_addr.s_addr = htonl(INADDR_ANY);<xhtml:br/>server_len = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);<xhtml:br/>
                           <xhtml:br/>bind(server_sockfd, (struct sockaddr *) &s1, server_len);</xhtml:div>
                     </xhtml:div>}</xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>This code may result in two servers binding a socket to same port, thus receiving each other's traffic. This could be used by an attacker to steal packets meant for another process, such as a secure FTP server.</Body_Text>
